snippet: In his first public appearance since a lackluster initial public offering in May, Facebook's chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, acknowledged the "disappointing" performance of its share price, but said the company continued to build new things in the...
abstract: In his first public appearance since a lackluster initial public offering in May, Facebook's chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, acknowledged the "disappointing" performance of its share price, but said the company continued to build new things in the face of criticism.
